headline.main: Scooter Riders May Be Required To Wear Helmets

docs.abstract: New York City Council considers bill requiring youths who ride scooters to wear helmets, citing rash of scooter-related injuries (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Less then a month after legislators introduced a bill taking aim at drivers who use cell phones, the City Council set its sights on the juvenile scooter set. This time, it is considering branding helmetless scooter tykes as outlaws. Some of the critics said that a helmet would take all of the fun out of the popular toys, which are sold from Main Street to Madison Avenue, relegating them to the back of the closet.

headline.main: Fearing One Fate, Women Ignore a Killer

docs.abstract: Dr Benjamin J Ansell article notes coronary heart disease is leading killer of American women; discusses why women fear breast cancer as killer much more than they do far more deadly heart disease; notes disparity of attention toward women's risk of heart disease extends to health care system; graph comparing heart disease and breast cancer mortality (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: American women understandably fear dying from breast cancer, given the numbers who will contract the disease at some point. Breast cancer can be a devastating illness, striking women with no apparent risk factors, often in the prime of life. Many will be subjected to disfiguring surgery, long-term chemotherapy and perhaps weeks of radiation treatment. Their physical scars often pale in comparison with damage to self-image and sexuality, coupled with fear of recurrence or a painful death.
docs.snippet: American women understandably fear dying from breast cancer, given the numbers who will contract the disease at some point. Breast cancer can be a devastating illness, striking women with no apparent risk factors, often in the prime of life.    Many...

headline.main: The State of Weight: Many Are Too Fat for the Calipers

docs.abstract: Prof John H Himes reports nearly 25 percent of American women in their 50's now have so much body fat that it cannot be measured in traditional way, using skinfold caliper; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Forging ahead on a path of seemingly endless weight gain, Americans have passed a singular milestone: nearly 25 percent of women in their 50's have so much body fat that it cannot be measured, at least not in the traditional way, which employs a device called a skinfold caliper to measure the layer of fat just beneath the skin. The statistic is ''new and striking,'' according to Dr. John H. Himes, a professor of epidemiology at the University of Minnesota, who described it in the January issue of The American Journal of Public Health. In an interview, Dr. Himes lamented the finding, not only because it underscores the epidemic of obesity in America, but also because it means the loss of a useful research tool. The calipers, he said, provide data about the distribution of body fat, which other measures do not yield.
